text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of a building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs to reach his apartment on the 10th floor.
However, on rainy days and when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.

Why does he normally get off on the 7th floor? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why the man takes the elevator down to the 7th floor every morning instead of going directly to the ground floor.
Let me start by breaking down the problem.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor.
That seems a bit odd because usually, you'd just take the elevator to your destination floor, right? But in this case, he's going all the way down.
Maybe there's a reason for that.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs to his apartment on the 10th floor.
So, he's not taking the elevator all the way home; he's stopping at the 7th floor and walking up.
Now, the twist is that on rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.
So, normally, he doesn't do that.

Why?

Hmm, maybe it's something about the elevator's behavior or the building's layout.
Let me think about elevators.
Sometimes, elevators have a limit to how high they go or maybe they have different compartments.
But the problem doesn't mention that.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator isn't working properly, but that's not specified either.
Wait, maybe it's about the time he takes.
If he takes the elevator all the way down to the ground floor every morning, that would take longer than just going to the 7th floor.
But the problem doesn't mention time constraints.
Or perhaps it's about the number of stops the elevator makes.
If he stops at the 7th floor in the evening, maybe he's trying to avoid waiting for the elevator on rainy days or when it's crowded.
Oh, I think I get it.
Let me think again.
On rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator, he takes the elevator directly to his apartment.
So, normally, he doesn't do that.
Why? Maybe because the elevator is slower or less frequent during rainy days, so he prefers to walk up the stairs instead of waiting for the elevator.
But that doesn't fully explain why he stops at the 7th floor normally.
Wait, perhaps the elevator has a rule where it doesn't go beyond the 7th floor unless there's a specific request.
Or maybe the man is trying to save time by getting off at the 7th floor and then walking up the stairs because the elevator is slower, especially during peak times.
But the problem says he takes the elevator down every morning, so maybe he's not saving time in the morning but is in the evening.
Alternatively, maybe the man works on the ground floor and needs to be there early, so he takes the elevator all the way down.
But that doesn't explain why he stops at the 7th floor in the evening.
Wait, another angle: perhaps the elevator only goes up to the 7th floor, so he has to get off there and walk up.
But the problem doesn't say that the elevator has a limit, so that might not be it.
Or maybe the man is trying to avoid other people in the elevator.
If he gets off at the 7th floor, he can walk up the stairs without encountering others who might be going to higher floors.
That makes sense because on rainy days or when there are many people, he prefers to go directly, so normally, he takes the elevator part of the way to avoid others.
So, putting it all together, the man takes the elevator down to the 7th floor because he wants to avoid other people in the elevator, especially in the morning when it's busy.
In the evening, when it's not as crowded or it's raining, he takes the elevator directly to his floor.
Normally, he stops at the 7th floor to walk up because he doesn't want to be around others in the elevator.

</think>

The man takes the elevator down to the 7th floor because he wants to avoid encountering other people in the elevator, especially during busy times.
In the evening, when it's not as crowded or it's raining, he takes the elevator directly to his apartment.
Normally, stopping at the 7th floor allows him to walk up the stairs without others being around, which he prefers to avoid.
